facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 145-A of 1954 was filed under Article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 145- A of 1954. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated July 23, 1954 of Madras High Court in Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 922 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated July 23, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 922 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on April 11, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: Pocker and B. K. B. Naidu, for the respondent. 1957. April 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-The appellant obtained a certificate

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from Madras High Court under Art. 132(1) for substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-The appellant obtained a certificate from the Madras High Court to the effect that the case involved a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution under Art. 132 1 , in companysequence of which the present appeal is before us.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under s.491 CrPC in High Court for habeas corpus and release from imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had filed a petition in the High Court under s. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure praying that directions in the nature of habeas companypus may be issued for his production before That Court to be dealt with according to law and for his release from imprisonment.

facts.text: Respondent arrested on June 1, 1954 pursuant to warrant issued on March 10, 1954 by Collector of Malabar under s.48 of Madras Revenue Recovery Act (Act 11 of 1864).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been arrested on June 1, 1954 in pursuance of a warrant issued on March 10, 1954 by the Collector of Malabar under s. 48 of the Madras Revenue Recovery Act  Madras Act 11 of 1864   hereinafter referred to as the Act . The circumstances, as stated in the affidavits filed by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer of Kozikhode in the High Court,

facts.text: Respondent assessed to income-tax with total outstanding tax of about Rs. 70,000.

anchor.surface_text: the total amount of tax remaining outstanding against him, in round figures, was Rs. 70,000. Some amount was recovered by the Collector in pursuance of a certificate issued by the Income Tax Officer under s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act and bY the Income Tax Officer himself under s. 46 5 A of the said Act.

facts.text: After recoveries, income-tax arrears were about Rs. 61,668 for assessment years 1943-44, 1945-46 to 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: After deducting the amount so realised the arrears of income-tax were about Rs. 61,668 and odd for the assessment Years 1943-44, 1945 -46 to 1948-49. Meanwhile the Income Tax Officer had made enquiries into the affairs of the respondent and had discovered that he had sold certain properties of his between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948

facts.text: Respondent sold properties between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948 for about Rs. 23,100.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the Income Tax Officer had made enquiries into the affairs of the respondent and had discovered that he had sold certain properties of his between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948 to the tune of about Rs. 23,100. Demand numberice had been served upon him on November 6, 1947 and the series of transactions of sale started on November 18, 1947.

facts.text: Demand notice served on respondent on November 6, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: to the tune of about Rs. 23,100. Demand numberice had been served upon him on November 6, 1947 and the series of transactions of sale started on November 18, 1947. Out of the said sum of Rs. 23,100, the respondent paid arrears of tax to the extent of Rs. 10,500 only.

facts.text: Out of Rs. 23,100 from sales, respondent paid Rs. 10,500 towards tax arrears.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the said sum of Rs. 23,100, the respondent paid arrears of tax to the extent of Rs. 10,500 only. Enquiries also revealed that although the respondent had closed his business at Cannanore in August, 1947,

facts.text: Respondent closed his business at Cannanore in August 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Enquiries also revealed that although the respondent had closed his business at Cannanore in August, 1947, he had set up a firm in 1948 at Tellichery carrying on an identical business in the name of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. companysisting of his one major and four minor sons.

facts.text: Respondent set up firm V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros in 1948 at Tellichery with one major and four minor sons, carrying identical business.

anchor.surface_text: he had set up a firm in 1948 at Tellichery carrying on an identical business in the name of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. companysisting of his one major and four minor sons. The respondent had alleged that the capital of this firm was mainly supplied from the sale of jewels belonging to his wife,

facts.text: Respondent alleged capital of firm supplied from sale of jewels belonging to his wife.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had alleged that the capital of this firm was mainly supplied from the sale of jewels belonging to his wife, that is, Abdul Azeezs mother. He denied that the above-mentioned firm belonged to him.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer found source of jewels not proved and held business of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros belonged to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: He denied that the above-mentioned firm belonged to him. In the assessment proceedings before the Income Tax Officer companycerning the firm V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros., the source of these jewels was gone into, but it was found that the same had number been proved and it was held that the business of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. belonged to the respondent.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer communicated facts to Collector who made independent enquiries.

anchor.surface_text: All these facts were companymunicated to the Collector by the Income Tax Officer who made independent enquiries for himself and had reason to believe that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of arrears of tax and had been guilty of fraudulent companyduct in evading payment of tax.

facts.text: Collector had reason to believe respondent wilfully withholding tax arrears and guilty of fraudulent conduct to evade payment.

anchor.surface_text: who made independent enquiries for himself and had reason to believe that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of arrears of tax and had been guilty of fraudulent companyduct in evading payment of tax. As a certificate had already been issued to him by the Income Tax Officer under s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act,

facts.text: Certificate issued by Income Tax Officer to Collector under s.46(2) Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: As a certificate had already been issued to him by the Income Tax Officer under s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act, the Collector proceeded under s. 48 of the Act to issue a warrant of arrest against the respondent in companysequence of which he was arrested and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore.

facts.text: Respondent arrested and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore.

anchor.surface_text: the Collector proceeded under s. 48 of the Act to issue a warrant of arrest against the respondent in companysequence of which he was arrested and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore. In the High Court, the petition under s. 491, Criminal Procedure Code,

facts.text: High Court petition under s.491 heard by Mack J. and Krishnaswami Nayudu JJ., allowed, respondent set at liberty, arrest held illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, the petition under s. 491, Criminal Procedure Code, was heard by Mack and Krishna. swamy Nayudu JJ. which was allowed and they ordered that the respondent be set at liberty as his arrest was illegal. Mack J. thought that s. 48 of the Act was ultra vires the Constitution as it offended Art. 22.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal with costs and set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

facts.text: Affidavits filed in High Court by Collector and Income Tax Officer of Kozhikode detailing circumstances of arrest.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances, as stated in the affidavits filed by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer of Kozikhode in the High Court, which led to the respondents arrest, were, that he had been assessed to income-tax for various assessment years

facts.text: Respondent was a man of about 70 years at time of arrest, suffering from serious ill health and paralysis.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the respondent was a man of about 70 years at the time of his arrest and a Person suffering from serious ill health. Indeed, it is said, he is suffering from paralysis and that he should number be sent back to jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: What we have to consider in this appeal, at the outset, is, whether either s. 48 of the Act or s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act or both offend Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the respondent was deprived of his personal liberty in accordance with a procedure established by law, i.e., a valid law

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal before us, the principal question, therefore, is whether the respondent was deprived of his personal liberty in accordance with a procedure established by law, i.e., a valid law.

holdings.text: s. 46(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act authorises the Collector to arrest the defaulting assessee via powers under revenue recovery acts like s.48

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this interpretation. The authority given to the Collector by this section is to recover the arrears of tax as if it were an arrear of land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.46(2) treats tax as land revenue arrears, invoking all recovery modes under s.5 Madras Act including execution against person (s.48)

holdings.text: s.48 does not require opportunity to be heard before issuing warrant of arrest

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in s. 48 of the Act which requires the Collector to give the defaulter an opportunity to be heard before arresting him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.48 requires only rational belief based on material; no textual mandate for pre-arrest hearing; court can review material post-arrest

holdings.text: arrest under s.48 is a mode of recovery of arrears, not punishment

anchor.surface_text: The preamble of the Act clearly states that the laws relating to the collection of the public revenue should be consolidated and simplified and s. 5 provides for the manner

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 lists modes: property sale or execution against person; s.48 is latter after property insufficient + wilful/fraudulent conduct; distinct from punitive sections

holdings.text: s.48 provides for release via s.46(2) proviso (CPC ss.58,59 powers) and cessation of condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: s. 48 of the Act does not in terms provide... but... proviso to s. 46 2 ... similar powers to that which a Civil Court has... s.58 CPC

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso s.46(2) confers civil court recovery powers incl. release on payment (CPC s.58); per Purshottam Halai; payment ends s.48 condition

anchor.surface_text: In Ajaib Singhs case... the taking into custody was not arrest and detention within the meaning of Art. 22... physical restraint... for civil debt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil debt recovery arrest not 'arrest/detention' under Art.22 absent criminal/quasi-criminal accusation; per Ajaib Singh

anchor.surface_text: In Purshottam Govindji Halais case, this Court held that there was no violation of Art. 21... s. 13 of the Bombay Land Revenue Act... constituted procedure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification for tax recovery; upheld in Purshottam Halai for analogous provision

holdings.text: Art.19(1)(a)-(e),(g) rights cannot be claimed if personal liberty lawfully deprived under Art.21

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in Gopalans case... that the right to move freely... when a person is lawfully deprived of his personal liberty without offending Art. 21

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Gopalan: Art.19 rights for freemen only; controlled by Art.21
